newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Dutch call money rises as market digests rate hike.
newsitem.headline: Dutch call money rises as market digests rate hike.

text.p: Dutch money market trading on Friday was reinvigorated by Thursday's 0.20-percent hike in the special advances rate to 2.70 percent.
Dealers said the rate increase was linked to the weaker guilder-mark rate and was aimed at reducing the gap on Germany's 3.0-percent repo rate.
But the guilder hardly reacted to the move and was quoted at 112.44 versus 112.42 on Thursday.
One dealer said the current 0.7-percent gap between the Dutch special advances rate and the secured loans rate was illogical.
"Now that we know what's happening, rates on the money market are likely to stabilise, and many parties are more confident about getting back into the market," one dealer said.
He said trade was fairly active compared to recent sluggishness. Trade focused on overnight money, which changed hands at 2.94 percent, and tomorrow next money.
Call rates were between 2.88 and 2.93 bid.
One dealer pointed out one- and six-month deposits were also more active, as increased certainty over short rates lured investors back.
One-month deposits were down four basis points from Thursday at 3.02 percent, while six-month deposits lost two basis points, bid at 3.10 percent.
Prices on the two new Dutch Treasury Certificates (DTCs), maturing on May 30 and December 31, were unchanged from Thursday at 3.07 and 3.16 percent, respectively.
